messages: b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (09:05): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Different colour channels seem to be on different pins so it doesn't seem like an impossible failure mode

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:27): are X3D models typically small enough to fit in text/html or big enough to need EXI?

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:01): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: any idea why the screensaver might have started asking for "the name and password of a user in the "(null)" group"? (and then not accepting any user names and passwords?)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:03): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: no idea
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:04): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I assume you mean the OS X screensaver?
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:04): why is "&notis;" tokenized as "&not;is;" and not like any other non-defined entity name? (just copying "&notis;" to output)
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (10:05): There's no such entity as notis;
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:05): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: because of backwards compat with &not
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (10:05): And there is an entity not
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (10:06): So the longest matching entity of "notis;" is "not".
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:06): hmm, so good-bye hash-tables, hello tries
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:07): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: this area is a bit of a pain and indeed hashtables won't work
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: no idea how to fix it, but it means a hard-reboot whenever my screensaver triggers
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:07): or any time i unsuspend
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:07): should get around to implementing this as a trie
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:07): a trie with suspendable search
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:07): and that makes sense as both Java and C++
002fd66affb058c756926402acf97570 (10:10): PHP html5lib basically uses a trie
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:11): wonders if it is alarmingly ignorant not to know what a trie is
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:11): wikipedia to rescue
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: try turning password locking off and back on perhaps?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:12): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: also: are you using fast user switching by any chance?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:12): (wild-ass guessing here)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:12): not using fast-user switching, though i did try toggling that to see if it had an effect
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:12): the password locking checkbox appears to be permanently disabled
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:12): probably some sort of corporate policy
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:13): do you not have admin rights on your machine?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:13): i do but that checkbox is still disabled
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (10:13): I did not know that was possible
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:13): me either
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): i discovered it about 10 seconds before you suggested toggling it :-)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:14): did entity matching in C++ just as a repeated binary search into a sorted array of entity strings
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): this machine has some weird stuff going on
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): e.g. it has two guest accounts
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): and if i disable login for one, the other one becomes enabled
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:14): it's quite odd

d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:15): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i'm thinking more of a static trie represented as sparse matrix and then packing it into a small table to avoid trie construction in runtime
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: I was thinking of packing the data in an int[] in Java
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:16): which would be ugly in C++ but would work there, too
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:16): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: hmm what do you mean by that?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:17): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: using an int[] as memory where pointers are indeces into the array (maybe more than one array for clarity)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:18): (avoiding run-time data structure construction in a way that works in both Java and C++ leads to quite some ugliness)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: In this case, might it be less ugly to write separate code for Java and C++?
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:19): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: ah, you mean using base + index instead of pointers
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:20): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you still get about ~80 branches before you get to desired charref :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:20): the construction of the entity tables has probably drawn the most complaints about any part of the C++ version of the parser
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:21): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: not if you use the character as an index and waste memory by having a lot of empty slots
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:22): Just special-case &nbsp; and then everything else is very rare and doesn't need to be fast :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:22): I've also considered using binary search plus then linear search outwards from the index binary search found
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:22): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: you don't if you pack the transition matrix (256 * number of state) into smaller ones with overlapping states
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:22): as a way to establish the search window in a naive table
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:23): let's make a competition :) faster lookup algorithm wins
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:23): you don't need to make it 256 wide
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:25): btw, http://ibawizard.net/~thement/pth/html5/
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:27): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: where do you keep the data on which entities require ;?
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: uh, come again?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:28): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: where do you keep data on which entities require a trailing semicolon
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:29): i had no idea there was such a case
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:33): "&alphax &gtx" = "&alphax >x"
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (10:33): I hope you weren't expecting a modicum of consistency here
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:34): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: you didn't notice that the entity table has duplicates of some entities but with a trailing semicolon?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:34): and some only have the version with the semicolon
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:34): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: no, i didn't go through them one-by-one
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:34): so longest match won't match unless there's the semicolon
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:36): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: i thought that the ref regex was \&[a-zA-Z]+;?
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:36): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: with parser error when semicolon is missing
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:36): d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca: everything is more complicated than it first seems
77dee1afd8563da9decaadfe7e067911 (10:38): whats this channel about
d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:38): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: thanks for pointing that out btw

378497080b0426fd127c5d45a5358550 (10:39): 77dee1afd8563da9decaadfe7e067911: The Web Hypertext Application Technology Working Group (WHATWG) is a growing community of people interested in evolving the Web. It focuses primarily on the development of HTML and APIs needed for Web applications.

d8cc952a670b1063df4c205ef5e920ca (10:41): ... is growing community of people reverse-engineering current browsers. It focuses primarily on the development of more realistic standards.

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:20): 77dee1afd8563da9decaadfe7e067911, pointer?
77dee1afd8563da9decaadfe7e067911 (11:21): aww, fixed
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:22): tries to work out what two suggestions Sam has made
77dee1afd8563da9decaadfe7e067911 (11:23): Now can someone help me with mine PLEASE
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:24): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I think neither suggestion is a good idea
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:25): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: I'm not particularly interested in deoptimizing any part of the parser for the sake of a most-favored JS library

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:25): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: and I don't want to add more interned string footprint and get complaints from other Gecko devs due to me adding too many interned strings
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:28): Sounds like HTML5's approach for integrating SVG and MathML is not sufficiently scalable for future centralised extensibility
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:28): SVG and MathML were grandfathered
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:29): future centralized extensibility should happen within the constraints of HTML, IMO
fe70b49783daa65bcb249805fb3a2b24 (11:29): sorry I got disconnected for a sec
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:29): checks logs
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:30): hmm looks like my comments got lost
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: seems like those both refer to the "special case X3D like SVG" suggestion?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (11:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, even with those constraints you'd get more interned strings, no?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: or was one of them about the "tag with uppercase letter and xmlns attribute triggers magic XML-like mode" suggestion?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:32): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: the upper case trigger was what I meant by "deoptimizing"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:32): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I see, cause you'd have to scan every tag? (or at least every tag with an xmlns attribute present)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:32): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: potentially, yes.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:34): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: if the first letter of a tag name is in upper case, how do I know if the name is going to be a known one?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:34): with the HTML5 solution, you could in theory only lazily intern the strings for vocabularies that you can only enter via a unique root element
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:35): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I suppose with Sam's proposal, you would not know what element to create until you parse the attributes
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:35): notes that making the language partially case-sensitive seems a horrid idea
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:35): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: not knowing until then is very unattractive
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:35): it's probably worth adding this fact-based information to the bug
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:36): (in terms of complexity and inconsistency in the language itself, regardless of implementation concerns)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:36): adding a completely X3D-specific hook seemed unappealing to me, but I hadn't thought through the effects of the case hack
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (11:39): heads away from the computer
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:41): tends to agree with ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:42): Irrespective of the practial problems with implementation the usability issues with the proposal seem overwhelming
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (11:46): Usability issues (positive or negative) should take priority over implementation issues anyway, so it seems more important to focus on the former
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:54): wonders if HTMLWG charter really allows for a task force that requires attendance of telecons
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:04): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea, no, the HTML WG's charter doesn't
